Secrecy is the lifeblood of our movement. Without it, our mission falters. The first rule is compartmentalization. No single individual holds the full picture. Each member knows only what is necessary for their role—no more, no less. Trust is earned through silence and loyalty tested through sacrifice. Those who speak too much, or to the wrong people, are made to disappear. Permanently.

Communication is fragmented. We use dead drops, coded messages, and disposable tools. The old methods—handwritten notes passed in plain sight—are still the most reliable. Technology is a double-edged blade. We use it, but only in ways that leave no trace. Burner phones, encrypted channels, and always, always a trail of false leads to misdirect the enemy. The authorities are watching, always watching, so we move like ghosts.

Recruitment is selective and subtle. We plant seeds in the right minds, those already broken by the system. A whisper here, a pamphlet there. The weak are the easiest to mold. We never reveal the full scope of our plans to new members. They must prove themselves first. And when they do, they are bound not by words, but by blood.

The enemy believes they control the narrative. They control the media, the schools, the courts. But they cannot control fear. They cannot control the truth we show to those who have nothing left. We strike where they do not expect, when they are least prepared. Precision and speed. A single act of righteous violence can shake their entire foundation.

To survive, we must be invisible. To strike, we must be inevitable. That is how we endure.
